prompt:
PROCEDURE: Chest Tube Placement
PATIENT: 45 F
INDICATION: recurrent effusion
SIDE: right
CATHETER: 14Fr
FLUID: 550ml serosanguinous
DOCTOR: Weiss
completion:
NOTE_ID: note_041
SOURCE_FILE: note_041.txt

INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date]

INDICATION FOR OPERATION
The patient is a 45-year-old female who presents with recurrent effusion.

CONSENT
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure were discussed with the patient in detail. The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Recurrent Effusion

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Recurrent Effusion

PROCEDURE
Ultrasound, chest (includes mediastinum), real time with image documentation (CPT 76604)
Insert catheter pleura with imaging (chest tube) (CPT 32557)

ATTENDING
Weiss

ANESTHESIA
Local ONLY: Lidocaine 1% (20 ml)

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS
Minimal

COMPLICATIONS
None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
Chest Ultrasound
Bedside ultrasound was performed on the right hemithorax.
Pleural Effusion: Large volume, anechoic echogenicity.
Loculations: None.
Diaphragmatic Motion: Normal.
Lung: Sliding was present before and after the procedure. Lung consolidation/atelectasis was present.
Pleura: Normal.
Images were saved and uploaded to the media tab.

Catheter Placement
The insertion site at the right 6th intercostal space, posterior-axillary line, was prepped and draped in a sterile fashion.
Local anesthesia was administered.
A 14Fr pigtail catheter was inserted using the Seldinger technique.
Entry into the pleural space was confirmed with the easy removal of minimal serosanguinous appearing pleural fluid.
A guidewire was inserted using the introducer needle pointed in the apical posterior direction, and the introducer needle was removed.
A dilator was inserted over the wire with a twisting motion to form a tract for catheter insertion.
The dilator was removed and the pigtail catheter (with trochar) was advanced over the guidewire.
The catheter was inserted until all catheter holes were well within the chest.
The guidewire and trochar were removed.

Drainage and Securement
The tube was attached to a Pleurovac collection drain apparatus.
Fluid Removed: 550 ml of serosanguinous fluid.
Suction: Applied at -20 cmH2O.
Securement: The catheter was sutured in place and covered.

SPECIMENS
None

IMPRESSION / PLAN
The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate complications.
Post-procedure chest x-ray ordered.
Continue chest tube to -20 cmH2O suction.
Maintain strict I/O.
Daily chest x-ray while chest tube is in place.
Nursing chest tube flushing protocol.
Continued care per primary team; disposition to ICU.

DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date]

INDICATION FOR OPERATION
The patient is a 68-year-old male who presents with recurrent effusion.

CONSENT
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure were discussed with the patient in detail. The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Recurrent Effusion

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Recurrent Effusion

PROCEDURE
Ultrasound, chest (includes mediastinum), real time with image documentation (CPT 76604)
Insert catheter pleura with imaging (chest tube) (CPT 32557)

ATTENDING
Ingraham

ANESTHESIA
Local ONLY: Lidocaine 1% (15 ml)

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS
Minimal

COMPLICATIONS
None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
Chest Ultrasound
Bedside ultrasound was performed on the left hemithorax.
Pleural Effusion: Large volume, anechoic echogenicity.
Loculations: None.
Diaphragmatic Motion: Normal.
Lung: Sliding was present before and after the procedure. Lung consolidation/atelectasis was present.
Pleura: Normal.
Images were saved and uploaded to the media tab.

Catheter Placement
The insertion site at the left 9th intercostal space, posterior-axillary line, was prepped and draped in a sterile fashion.
Local anesthesia was administered.
A 12Fr pigtail catheter was inserted using the Seldinger technique.
Entry into the pleural space was confirmed with the easy removal of minimal straw-colored appearing pleural fluid.
A guidewire was inserted using the introducer needle pointed in the apical posterior direction, and the introducer needle was removed.
A dilator was inserted over the wire with a twisting motion to form a tract for catheter insertion.
The dilator was removed and the pigtail catheter (with trochar) was advanced over the guidewire.
The catheter was inserted until all catheter holes were well within the chest.
The guidewire and trochar were removed.

Drainage and Securement
The tube was attached to a Pleurovac collection drain apparatus.
Fluid Removed: 1425 ml of straw-colored fluid.
Suction: Applied at -20 cmH2O.
Securement: The catheter was sutured in place and covered.

SPECIMENS
None

IMPRESSION / PLAN
The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate complications.
Post-procedure chest x-ray ordered.
Continue chest tube to -20 cmH2O suction.
Maintain strict I/O.
Daily chest x-ray while chest tube is in place.
Nursing chest tube flushing protocol.
Continued care per primary team; disposition to ICU.

INDICATION FOR OPERATION
The patient is a 52-year-old female who presents with recurrent malignant effusion.

CONSENT
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure were discussed with the patient in detail. The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Recurrent Malignant Effusion

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Recurrent Malignant Effusion

PROCEDURE
Ultrasound, chest (includes mediastinum), real time with image documentation (CPT 76604)
Insert catheter pleura with imaging (chest tube) (CPT 32557)

ATTENDING
Chen

ANESTHESIA
Local ONLY: Lidocaine 1% (5 ml)

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS
Minimal

COMPLICATIONS
None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
Chest Ultrasound
Bedside ultrasound was performed on the right hemithorax.
Pleural Effusion: Large volume, anechoic echogenicity.
Loculations: None.
Diaphragmatic Motion: Normal.
Lung: Sliding was present before and after the procedure. Lung consolidation/atelectasis was present.
Pleura: Normal.
Images were saved and uploaded to the media tab.

Catheter Placement
The insertion site at the right 6th intercostal space, posterior-axillary line, was prepped and draped in a sterile fashion.
Local anesthesia was administered.
A 14Fr pigtail catheter was inserted using the Seldinger technique.
Entry into the pleural space was confirmed with the easy removal of minimal serosanguinous appearing pleural fluid.
A guidewire was inserted using the introducer needle pointed in the apical posterior direction, and the introducer needle was removed.
A dilator was inserted over the wire with a twisting motion to form a tract for catheter insertion.
The dilator was removed and the pigtail catheter (with trochar) was advanced over the guidewire.
The catheter was inserted until all catheter holes were well within the chest.
The guidewire and trochar were removed.

Drainage and Securement
The tube was attached to a Pleurovac collection drain apparatus.
Fluid Removed: 550 ml of serosanguinous fluid.
Suction: Applied at -15 cmH2O.
Securement: The catheter was sutured in place and covered.

SPECIMENS
None

IMPRESSION / PLAN
The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate complications.
Post-procedure chest x-ray ordered.
Continue chest tube to -15 cmH2O suction.
Maintain strict I/O.
Daily chest x-ray while chest tube is in place.
Nursing chest tube flushing protocol.
Continued care per primary team; disposition to ICU.
